awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Evaluation of ACA Reform
awd_abstract_narration:
At the core of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) is the "individual mandate" law. Under this law, each individual in the ACA's "health insurance exchanges" needs to buy coverage or pay a penalty. Individual mandate has perhaps been the most controversial part of the ACA. This research aims at answering two crucial questions about this law. First, by how much would the uninsurance rate increase after lifting individual mandate? Second, to what extent could the proposed replacements to this law mitigate the negative impact of that lift on coverage?

This research develops an economic model of healthcare exchanges that incorporates asymmetric information and consumer dynamics. It allows for heterogeneity in health statuses of individuals, enabling it to capture adverse selection -- the main reason why the market could collapse without individual mandate. The model is dynamic, allowing it to capture consumers' foresighted decision making. This is crucial for evaluating the impact of the proposed replacements to individual mandate, which all penalize consumers who stay uninsured today with restricted access to health insurance in the future. Using the model, the investigators examine how different ways to replace or reform the ACA might affect the performance of the health insurance exchange and the consumer welfare.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
At the time of the passage of the Affordable Care Act (ACA), about 50 million Americans did not have health insurance. 14 years later half that number remain uninsured despite heavy subsidization of both health insurance premiums and out-of-pocket medical costs.

Lack of take-up in the presence of subsidies is suggestive of impediments to individuals' participation in health insurance markets. We estimate the role of different frictions to participation in the exchanges, such as: uncompensated care, myopia and distaste for complying with the ACA mandate. We do so by estimating demand for health insurance by individuals who were not offered insurance by their employer nor qualified for government provided coverage (e.g., Medicaid or Medicare). We use MEPS data to estimate preference for insurance. MEPS has information on insurance coverage, and is particularly useful as it has information on uncompensated care. 

The main question we ask is which participation inducements are most effective: subsidies and penalties of the sort associated with the ACA, or the penalties proposed Republicans during the prior administration. For example, the American Health Care Act (ACHA) bill passed by the House of Representatives would have required an individual whose coverage has lapsed (i.e., one who remains uninsured for at least 63 days) to pay a 30% surcharge in premium for one year in case she decides to re-enroll. The Senate version required that an individual whose coverage lapses to be denied insurance for six months. These penalty schemes differ from their ACA counterpart in that they create dynamic incentives. A healthy individual may purchase coverage even when healthy for fear of future health deterioration.

Our demand estimates attribute limited participation to a large extend to uncompensated care and myopia, while distaste for insurance seems to play a limited role. 

We use the estimated preference (friction) parameters to simulate the functioning of the exchanges under different rules. Once we have predicted prices and individual behavior, we compute welfare under the different rules.

We find that risk pricing (no community rating) and the dynamic penalty regimes lead to higher participation than ACA-type penalties. Subsidies are essential to induce participation under ACA rules, but less necessary under risk pricing and the dynamic penalties. 

In terms of frictions, removing myopia or uncompensated care leads to substantial increase in participation. Removing both leads to full participation, even without subsidies.

We compute welfare under both a myopic criterion and a paternalistic one. The former reflects the welfare of a consumer who misperceives downwards her upcoming out of pocket (OOP) expenses. The paternalistic criterion takes full account of the actual distribution of expected OOP expenses.

While risk pricing leads to high participation, it delivers lower welfare than the ACA under both criteria. The main reason is reclassification risk. Full participation is the preferred regime even under the myopic view. The dynamic surcharge does better than the ACA but is dominated by full participation. The last result highlights the extent of adverse selection at play.

Absent subsidies risk pricing would do better than ACA-type community rating. The unravelling of the market would be so extensive that reclassification risk would be more palatable.

The framework permits simulating different policies, assessing their welfare and budgetary impact.

Modified by: Igal Hendel
